9.97.text:
In 1916, World War One became a war of attrition.
Both sides began to focus less on winning

18.97.text:
victory on the battlefield, than grinding
down the enemy, and inflicting such enormous

24.98.text: losses they would be forced to surrender.

28.71.text:
In 1917, the strategy will push Europe's major
powers to the brink of collapse.

39.24.text:
Germany knows it will lose a long war of attrition
against the Allies, who have greater resources.

54.54.text:
So its leaders gamble: they resume unrestricted
submarine warfare, believing their U-boats

62.11.text:
can cut off Britain's food imports by sea,
and starve the country into surrender within

72.06.text:
But the new shoot-on-sight tactics mean neutral
American ships will inevitably be caught in

78.38.text:
the crossfire, risking America joining the
war on the Allied side.

84.49.text:
Just two days into the campaign, the SS Housatonic,
an American steamer carrying wheat from Galveston,

92.05.text: Texas to England, is sunk by a U-boat.

97.74.text:
The British then pass to the US government
a telegram they've intercepted, from German

103.05.text:
foreign secretary Arthur Zimmermann to the
German ambassador in Mexico.

110.03.text:
Germany is encouraging Mexico to attack America,
if America and Germany end up at war.

118.33.text:
The so-called Zimmermann Telegram puts yet
more pressure on US President Wilson to declare

133.61.text:
In Russia, enormous casualties and bread shortages
lead to riots... and revolution. The Tsar

144.77.text:
abdicates. A Provisional Government takes
charge, pledging to continue the war. But

149.95.text:
at the front, Russian troops begin to desert
en masse.

157.37.text:
After a string of German provocations, the
US finally declares war on Germany. It brings

164.74.text:
immense resources to the Allied cause, but
they will take many months to mobilise.

171.44.text:
And the German gamble of unrestricted submarine
warfare may still pay off. April is the U-boats

178.84.text:
most successful month of the war: they sink
886,000 tons of Allied shipping, an average

187.32.text:
of 17 ships a day, all packed with urgently-needed
food and supplies.

194.55.text:
Britain will face starvation if the U-boats
are not defeated soon.

202.41.text:
On the Western Front, the British launch the
Battle of Arras - a diversion, to support

212.11.text:
After heavy fighting, Canadian troops seize
the high ground of Vimy Ridge. Its a limited

218.90.text:
Allied victory, but costs 150,000 Allied casualties,
to 130,000 German.

228.73.text:
Above the trenches, the first air war has
reached new levels of sophistication and deadliness.

236.57.text:
Reconnaissance aircraft are crucial for spotting
enemy positions, and directing artillery fire

242.02.text:
onto them. Scout aircraft, or fighters, try
to shoot them down before they can execute

252.79.text:
New models of aircraft are developed every
few months. But that spring, the superiority

258.24.text:
of German aircraft leads to heavy Allied losses,
in what becomes known as 'Bloody April'.

273.39.text:
Three days after the fall of Vimy Ridge, French
General Robert Nivelle launches his main offensive.

281.86.text:
Expectations are high, but after initial success
the advance bogs down and casualties quickly

300.19.text:
The apparently senseless losses cause morale
in the French army to collapse. Whole units

311.46.text:
General Nivelle is sacked as French commander-in-chief,
and replaced by General Pétain, hero of Verdun,

319.34.text: who promises no more suicidal attacks.

325.99.text:
That summer, at Messines Ridge, the British
tunnel under the German lines, and detonate

332.57.text:
19 enormous mines under the enemy position.
Its the largest man-made explosion in history

341.21.text:
to date, and paves the way to a brilliant
but highly local British victory.

349.70.text:
In Greece, King Constantine, who has favoured
neutrality, is forced to abdicate, and Greece

367.52.text:
Russia's Provisional Government orders a new
attack, but the July Offensive is a disaster:

372.60.text:
the morale and discipline of the Russian army
has collapsed. It can no longer be relied

380.31.text:
on to fight, and the Central Powers' counterattack
is almost unopposed.

389.60.text:
At sea, the Allies begin to group their merchant
ships into convoys, which sail under naval

396.56.text:
escort. The new system leads to a steady fall
in losses.

402.36.text: The tide is turning in the U-boat war.

409.05.text:
As discontent with the war grows in Germany,
the German parliament, the Reichstag, passes

415.13.text:
a 'Peace Resolution', calling for 'a peace
of understanding and reconciliation'.

422.08.text:
It's ignored by the German High Command, which
now effectively rules the country as a military

431.88.text:
In Belgium, the British launch their major
offensive of 1917, the Third Battle of Ypres.

440.31.text: It will be remembered as Passchendaele.

445.24.text:
Heavy shelling, rain and broken irrigation
channels turn the battlefield into a sea of

450.94.text:
mud. In these impossible conditions, all hopes
of a breakthrough soon fade.

459.61.text:
The attack is called off after 3 months, by
which point the British have suffered 240,000

468.98.text:
On the 
Italian Front, at the 11th Battle of the Isonzo,
Italian and Austro-Hungarian forces batter

484.88.text:
each other into exhaustion. There are 150,000
Italian casualties, 100,000 Austro-Hungarian.

499.06.text:
That year, 1917, the list of Allied nations
grows. Brazil... Liberia... China... and Siam...

510.32.text:
all declare war on Germany, as a result of
German U-boat attacks, or to curry favour

516.18.text:
with the Allies. China will contribute many
thousands of labourers, working for the Allies

523.21.text: in Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

537.66.text:
That year in the Middle East, British forces
avenge their 1916 humiliation at Kut, by defeating

544.96.text:
the Ottoman Turks and marching on to occupy
Baghdad.

553.08.text:
British forces in Egypt advance across the
Sinai Desert, but are thrown back by Ottoman

559.12.text:
forces at the First and Second Battles of
Gaza.

565.56.text:
In July, Arab rebels capture the strategic
Ottoman port of Aqaba. They are accompanied

573.07.text:
by a British military advisor, Captain T.E.
Lawrence, better known as 'Lawrence of Arabia'.

581.36.text:
That autumn, British foreign secretary Arthur
Balfour issues the 'Balfour Declaration',

590.06.text:
expressing support for the creation of a national
home for the Jews in Palestine.

597.31.text:
The aim is to rally Jewish support for the
Allies, but the declaration contradicts existing

607.60.text:
In October, the British finally win at Gaza,
clearing the way for an advance into Palestine.

622.11.text:
Six weeks later, General Allenby leads British
troops into Jerusalem, ending 400 years of

638.86.text:
With Russian forces in disarray, Germany is
able to move troops from the East to the Italian

645.29.text:
Front. At the Battle of Caporetto, they help
to smash through the Italian army, advancing

653.59.text: 70 miles and taking quarter of a million prisoners.

660.11.text:
British and French divisions, desperately
needed on the Western Front, have to be redeployed

671.48.text:
In Russia, a second revolution brings Lenin's
Bolshevik Party to power. He is determined

678.37.text: to end Russia's involvement in the war.

682.92.text:
In France, Georges Clemenceau becomes Prime
Minister. Nicknamed 'the Tiger', he promises

694.30.text:
But for the Allies in late 1917, final victory
looks uncertain: Russia has stopped fighting;

702.83.text:
French armies are recovering from mutiny;
the Italian front has almost collapsed. And

709.96.text:
American reinforcements still seem a long
way off.

714.09.text:
For the time being, the British are the only
effective Allied force in the field...

723.11.text:
So the British attack at Cambrai, with the
first major tank assault in history.

730.35.text:
On the first day, nearly 400 tanks spearhead
an advance of several miles through German

736.47.text:
defences. But then the tanks break down or
are knocked out; the Germans rush in reinforcements,

759.87.text:
Rumania, isolated by the Russian collapse,
signs an armistice with the Central Powers.

768.83.text:
Six days later, Russia also signs an armistice.
The Allied Eastern Front is no more.

777.84.text:
1917 has seen one major Allied power, Russia,
knocked out of the war – but the arrival

786.54.text: of a fresh, new ally, America.

790.92.text:
Germany knows only military victory can now
save it from being overwhelmed by Allied resources,

798.04.text:
and begins planning one last, massive onslaught,
for the spring of 1918.
